VOT Certification Standard

International Fog Grading Consortium • Rev. 4.2 • Amended March 2024

Viscosity

Resistance to airflow at 20°C, measured in milliPascal-seconds

V-Scale Protocol: Specimens are suspended in a sealed 1m³ acrylic chamber at 20°C ± 0.2°. A calibrated 40mm brass sphere is dropped from 800mm. Fall time in milliseconds determines the V-rating. Ratings below 3 are classified as "barely there." Ratings above 8 require a hazmat glove. she had a V-9 laugh. thick enough to slow you down.

Opacity

Light transmittance percentage, inverse scale

O-Scale Protocol: A 100-lumen LED is positioned 500mm from a photocell. The specimen is released between them. The percentage of light blocked determines the O-rating. An O-1 fog is a suggestion. An O-10 fog is a wall. Most customers prefer O-4 through O-6: enough to change the room without losing the furniture. I wanted an O-10 to hide in but kept buying O-3s because I'm a coward

Tactility

Dermal perception index, 10-point haptic scale

T-Scale Protocol: Subjects place their forearm into a cloud column. They report sensation on a 10-point scale from "did I touch anything?" (T-1) to "someone is holding my hand" (T-10). The T-scale is the least scientific of the three. We keep it anyway. a T-7 once made a grown man cry at a trade show in Denver
grading grief on a 10-point scale

Ethical Sourcing & Cloud Preservation

Sustainability Statement

TouchFog sources all atmospheric specimens using 100% renewable-energy condensation arrays deployed at altitude-appropriate collection sites. Our field teams operate under strict no-trace protocols. No ecosystem is disturbed. No weather pattern is altered. We take only what the sky was already releasing.

Each specimen is captured in medical-grade borosilicate containers, sealed under nitrogen atmosphere, and transported in phase-change temperature-controlled packaging. Our carbon offset program plants one cloud-seeding silver iodide canister for every 500 units shipped.

We are certified by the International Fog Grading Consortium (IFGC), the North American Atmospheric Commerce Board (NAACB), and our moms.

Cloud Preservation Guide

Document ref: TP-PRV-2024-08 • Classification: Public

ParameterOptimalAcceptableCritical

Humidity85–92%75–95%<60%

VibrationNone<0.5g>2g
Container SealNitrogenArgonAmbient

Upon opening, release specimen in a sealed room at target temperature. Close doors and windows. Minimize air circulation. Do not attempt to contain the cloud once released. Do not attempt to re-capture a dispersing specimen.

Note: all clouds dissipate. This is not a defect.
